dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: City lights. The soaring bridges and glowing windows of N York City. The SOUNDS of a cocktail party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A party   of bohemian types in the village. Artist's canv propped   up against the walls. A narrow hallway with cou talking   intimately. Two rooms crammed with young people smoking   and drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man and a woman in their 20's stand alone in a corner..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK WHEELER, intelligent good-looks, and APRIL JOHNSON, patrician beauty, a woman amongst girls. He's been making her laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm studying to be an actress. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a longshoreman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) No, I mean really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean really too. Starting Monday, though, I'm doing something a little more glamorous. Night cashier at a cafeteria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I don't mean how you make money.   I mean what are you interested in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey - if I had the answer to that one, I bet I'd bore us both to death in half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs.   He smiles, revelling in her attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Frank and April dance. They move well, in sync, looking into each other's eyes. He slides his hand down t silk of April's dress until it rests in the small of her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on their hands. Their fingers slowly entwine as the lose themselves in each other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Frank's face, seven years later, full of doubt a tension as he watches his wife, April, on stage and as we hear the hollow VOICES of a very bad amateur play...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, mercifully, the curtain falls.   Nothing.   Then vigorous, relieved applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank hears a voice from behind, through the applause:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOMAN Thank God that's over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April takes the final bow. She's fighting not to cry. Fra applauds her loudly. Looks around to see who else is join him. But there is no noticeable crescendo in the applause

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Frank hears the voice again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOMAN (CONT'D) ...And she was very disappointing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't argue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank now moves against the crowd of exiting audience mem towards the stage. He keeps his head lowered, avoiding ey contact, until he feels a hand on his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. AND MRS. GIVINGS, an older couple, are standing in hi way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Frank! Very nice Frank!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Thanks, Mrs. Givings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank steps around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS I can't tell you how much we enjoyed it. You have a very talented wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank forces a smile as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I'll pass it along!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April sits alone at her dressing table crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAST mills backstage. The mood is subdued, but some h decided to make light of the disaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank moves through the crowd.    Across the room, he see

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILLY CAMPBELL, 30's, determinedly bright, up on her tip- toes. Her husband SHEP, 30's, heavy-set, is still in costume, shell-shocked and pebbled with sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILLY Frank!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Hi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILLY She's through there...! (points) You `bout ready for that drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Couple of minutes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank enters. The chair in front of the mirror is empty. cigarette burns in the ashtray. Frank glances at a standi screen in the corner. April's costume is draped over the top. He goes towards it, deciding what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartfelt) April, sweetheart.   You were great. I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the bathroom opens. April enters in street clothes. Frank's been talking to an empty room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Hi. You about ready to leave? I've just got to get this makeup off, then we can go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits in front of the mirror, too embarrassed to look him. FRANK can see that her face is blotchy from crying. puts his hand on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Well... I guess it wasn't a triumph or anything, was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL looks at him in the mirror. She holds his look just second. And from her expression, he knows he said exactly the wrong thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL I guess not. I'll be ready in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Take your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He removes his hands and lights a cigarette.     APRIL be take off her makeup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Will you do me a favor? Milly and Shep wanted us to go out with them afterwards. Will you say we can't? Say it's because of the baby sitter or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Well, the thing is, I already said that we could. I mean, I just saw them out there and I said we would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL (tense) Oh. Then would you mind going out again and saying you were mistaken? That should be simple enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Don't you think that's a little bit rude, April?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Well I'll tell them myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. Take it easy. I'll tell them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He backs to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April and Frank walk down a long empty echoing corridor, school lockers, booster club posters and silent classroom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't touch.   They don't speak.   The tension betwe them is palpable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank drives. April stares ahead.    Their faces are lit the dashboard. After a while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I mean it, baby. You were the only person in that play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK We just never should've let you get mixed up in the damned thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK You've studied for Christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Could we sort of stop talking about it now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Sure. I just don't want you feeling bad about it, that's all. Because it's not worth it. I mean, it's bad enough having to live out here among these damn people - what'd you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL I said yes. All right, Frank. Could you just stop talking now, before you drive me crazy, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank clenches his jaw and flips on the indicator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL (CONT'D) What are you doing? Why are we stopping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car comes to a stop at the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank turns off the ignition.   He slides towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL No, Frank, please don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Baby, it's okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Please don't touch me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Why can't you...just... LEAVE ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank slides back behind the wheel.    Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK It strikes me, that there's a considerable amount of bullshit going on here.... And there's one or two things I'd like to clear up. Number one, it's not my fault the play was lousy. Number two, it's sure as hell not my fault you didn't turn out to be an actress, and the sooner you get over that little piece of soap opera the better off we'll both be. Number three, I don't happen to fit the role of dumb, insensitive suburban husband; you've been trying to hang that one on me ever since we moved here. Number four -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door and is out of the car, flashing across headlights. Frank struggles with his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April stands in the dark 30 yards from the road looking o an expansive countryside. There's only a few lights in th distance. This is still farmland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank comes up behind her, careful to keep his distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK What the hell are you doing?     Come back to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL No. Just let me stand here a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank raises his arms in exasperation. A car approaches. puts a hand in his pocket and tries to look casual. The car's headlights light up April's back, then pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK April?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) Look, can't we sit in the car and talk about it, instead of running all over Route Twelve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Haven't I made it clear I don't particularly want to talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Okay. Jesus, I'm trying to be nice about this thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL How kind of you. How terribly, terribly kind of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Wait a minute. I don't deserve this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL You're always so wonderfully definite, aren't you, on the subject of what you do and don't deserve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and walks past him back towards the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stumbles after her.   Other cars whizz by, but he's pa caring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) Wait a minute, God damn it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans against the car and folds her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) You listen to me. This is one time you're not going to get away with twisting everything I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Christ, I wish you'd stayed home tonight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK You know what you are when you're like this? You're sick. I really mean that. You're sick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL And you know what you are? (eyes raking him) You're disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Just because you've got me safely in this little trap, you think you can bully me into feeling whatever you want!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK You in a trap! You in a trap! Jesus, don't make me laugh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Yes, me. (clutching at her chest) Me! Me! Me! Oh, you poor, pathetic little boy В­В­ Look at you! Look at you, and tell me how by any stretch of the imagination you can call yourself a man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises his fist, she flinches away, and BONG! BONG! BO BONG! He punches the hood of the car. Then, silence. The look April gives him is probably the worst look he's ever received: a look of pitying boredom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Don't look at me like that, April.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Could we please go home now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She calmly walks around and gets in the car.    After a m Frank follows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit silently in the car in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, attractive suburban house in the morning sunshin Frank walks out to the car, stops and looks back at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April stands at the window.   The SOUND of the car pullin away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stands on a grey platform, amongst a crowd of commuters. The morning commuter train eases into the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits against the train window holding a "New Yorker Around him, the train is crowded with men reading newspap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In one swift movement, all the doors of the commuter trai swing open as a hundred feet step down onto the platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty stairwell in Grand Central: a tide of grim, determined commuters rise into view. A mass of suits and hats. Frank is amongst them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knox Headquarters -- a squat, formidable structure.   Thi HONKING traffic. Crowded sidewalks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank walks with the crowd past a display window: bright cardboard images of fashionable women grin and point thei pencils at a list of product benefits - "SPEED, ACCURACY,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pride of place at the center of the display is a new Knox Electronic Computer with a sign that reads: "Performs A M Lifetime of Work in Just 30 Minutes!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank rides crushed against the wall in a crowded elevato He glances over at -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN GRUBE, 23, ripe, a little obvious, but undeniably sexy.   She meets his look. And looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank opens the bottom right drawer of his desk, props up feet and lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK (O.S.) I'm going to need your help this morning, Old Scout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated beside Frank, JACK ORDWAY, 40's, tall and effete w greying hair, appears to be hard at work, hunched over a file. He is, in fact, propping up his head with his hand while shielding his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK (CONT'D) For the next few hours, you're to warn me of Bandy's every approach and you may have to screen me from public view in the likely event I that I throw up. It's that bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Good morning, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK Nothing good about it, I assure you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April drags two overflowing garbage cans to the curb. She stops and looks down the empty road. Not a single human being in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on April's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Givings sits behind the wheel, driving slowly along suburban street talking at high speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits beside her wearing sunglasses.    April sits i back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't yet see what Mrs. Givings is describing, only as plays on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I knew the moment you came off the train what you were looking for... A small remodeled barn, or a carriage house В­ And I just hate to be the one to tell you that sort of thing just isn't available anymore... But I don't want you to despair. There is one place down here I want to show you... Now of course it isn't very desirable at this end. (gestures) As you see, Crawford Road is mostly these little cinder-blocky, pick-up trucky places В­ plumbers, carpenters, little local people of that sort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank turns around to April, lowers his glasses. April stifles a giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS (CONT'D) But eventually... (she points, her arm fully extended) Eventually it leads up to Revolutionary Road, which is much nicer. Now, the place I want to show you, is a sweet little house and a sweet little setting. Simple, clean lines, good lawns, marvelous for children. It's right around this next curve... Now, you'll see it В­ there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS (CONT'D) See the little white one? Sweet isn't it? The perky way it sits there on its little slope? Charming, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April smiles.    A smile full of promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's FIST raps against the door of an office...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TED BANDY, 46, tight and precise, looks up from behind a organized desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK You wanted to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandy holds out an envelope from behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANDY Came for you from Toledo this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank reaches for it, but Bandy moves it out of reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANDY (CONT'D) This is the third one this month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Oh, right, sorry. I thought I'd taken care of that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank reaches again, but Bandy moves it.   A little man enjoying his power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANDY I'm not prepared to have this conversation again, Frank. You understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK ...Absolutely, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANDY These folks in the provinces look up to us, Frank.    We need to be efficient. We can't have this kind of back and forth, and so forth. It's just not efficient. Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK ...Absolutely, yes, yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandy finally hands over the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK What was that about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Toledo. Branch manager wants a revised brochure for the conference on "The Knox 500." (impersonating Bandy) "It's just not efficient."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK (sharp inhale) Sounds like a real goodie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I don't even know what the Knox 500 does... Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK Don't insult me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank drops it in his In Box. Then, looking up, he sees Maureen across the office. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stands over Maureen at her desk.   The envelope fro Toledo lies in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Now, if you'll look in the inactive file under SP-1109 you'll find copies of all the stuff we sent to the agency... and that way we can trace the thing back to its original sources.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, jotting down a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, Frank allows himself to take in her profile, her cleavage, her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) I hope you weren't planning on an early lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN I'm not really hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Good. I'll check on you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen and Frank sit in a secluded corner.    Maureen si martini. She's already a little drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) You know something? You're lucky you met me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?    How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I can show you the ropes. There's an art to survival at Knox. Let me show you what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves over the waiter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) Bring me the telephone would you? And two more martinis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen looks daunted at her empty glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter brings over the phone. Frank dials. He holds h finger to his lips. He uses an authoritative tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Hello Mrs. Jorgensen. Frank Wheeler here. Just wanted to let you know that I've had to send Maureen Grube down to Visual Aides for me. I'll probably need her the rest of the day... Okay? Fine. You too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank hangs up and smiles at Maureen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN I never even heard of Visual Aides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK That's because it doesn't exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we're moving behind April as she moves through the si house. She carries a basket of dirty laundry on her hip. She pulls the bedding off the couch. The distant SOUND of children playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yoo-hoo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to see Mrs. Givings at the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April manages a friendly smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS I can't stay a minute... My, don't you look comfy! I just wanted to bring this sedum for that messy patch in the front yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS (CONT'D) All it wants is just a tiny dollop of water for the first few days, and you'll find it absolutely thrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Well, thank you... You want some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Only if you're having some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen sits down. With the end of her finger, she pushes a dirty dish out of her way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Is there something I can do for you, Helen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Oh... yes, I almost forgot. I do have a small favor I'd like to ask... (quiver of anxiety ) It's about my son, John. He's been in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL I'm sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Well, actually, just for the present, he's in Pleasant Brook... Psychiatric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April's face.   She knows what it means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL ...I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Oh... Nothing serious. He just got a little run down. Things can just get the better of us sometimes. Don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.    Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Givings smiles. Then, pretending to read the titles a stack of books on the table...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS It really is a marvellous facility and the treatments seem to be doing him wonders... Anyway, they said getting out for an afternoon might do him some good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pauses on Sartre's `Nausea', looks at it vaguely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS (CONT'D) I think he finds my friends a little conventional, frankly. I mean, he's travelled. He has a PhD in mathematics. I suppose you could say he's an intellectual. It would do him a world of good to meet a young couple like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL We'd love to Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS So, I thought perhaps if you had some time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL We'd love to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS (flushed with relief) Thank you, dear... Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April smiles generously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS (CONT'D) I remember when you first came off the train. You weren't like most of my clients. You were different, somehow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April's face.    She's listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS (CONT'D) Well, you looked simply ravishing and I just knew Frank did something terribly brilliant in town. You just seemed... special... Of course you still are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April watches from the picture window as Mrs. Givings wal down the drive towards her car. Her face is reflected in glass. Something is taking shape in her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dining room is now almost empty.     Waiters and busb in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank cuts a solitary figure.     He lights his last ciga and crumples the pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN (O.S.) I guess you got me a little drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen slides into the booth.     She stares at the tabl trying to focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK You know what today is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Monday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my birthday.      I'm thirty years old today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN Happy birthday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen raises her glass, then sways drunkenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN (CONT'D) What was the name of the department you made up again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Visual Aides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN ...What-a-joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sips his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Want to hear a real joke...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) My old man worked at Knox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK He was a salesman in Yonkers. Once a year he used to take me into the city for lunch. It was supposed to be a special, life-advice sort of occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Not really... I used to sit there and think, `I hope to Christ I don't end up like you.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank grins as if it's supposed to be very funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) And here I am, a thirty year old Knox man. Can you beat that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN I think I kind of lost you...   Your father worked for Knox...? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN (CONT'D) I'm sorry, but everything's kinda going out of focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank takes her arm to steady her.   She meets his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK How `bout some air?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a hand opening an old cigar box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April is sitting with the box at the kitchen table. It contains various sentimental knickknacks from her past, including photos of the kids, of her and Frank in New Yor with friends, and a photograph of Frank in uniform beneat the Eifel tower on liberation day... She studies it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank fixes coffee in the tiny kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April is sitting up in bed in the first blue light of day wearing Frank's T-shirt. She holds a curled collection of black and white photographs in her lap. She stops on the same picture of Frank and the Eifel Tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank comes over with the coffee, and two cigarettes. lights them both, and gives her one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK You ever been to Paris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL I've never really been anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Maybe I'll take you with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lies down with his cigarette between his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) I'm going back first chance I get. People are alive there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares up at the ceiling.    She studies him.   Apprai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) All I know now is that I want to feel things. Really feel them. How's that for an ambition...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Frank Wheeler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL I think you're the most interesting person I've ever met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her, overwhelmed by her face in the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stands at the mantle tying his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Well, I guess this wasn't what you had in mind when you went to work this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen covers herself with the sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   It certainly wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank inspects the contents of the mantle: photos of Maur at the prom; Maureen with her parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen tentatively fingers her hair that has now gone to frizz. The sheet slips down. She grabs at it. Then wills herself to calm down and act sophisticated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN (CONT'D) Do you have a cigarette, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Sure, here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes over and gives her one. Lights it with his Zippo She exhales, slowly gaining confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank gets up and pulls on his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN Can I get you a drink or anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK No thanks, Maureen. Actually, I guess I'd better be cutting out, it's getting kind of late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN Gee, that's right.   Have you missed your train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK It's all right, I'll get the next one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes over to her.   Bends down, kisses her gently on lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) Listen: you were swell. Take care now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's station car turns into the driveway.     He sits moment in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank approaches the door with his key. He takes a moment gather himself, but before he can, the door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April is dressed in a black cocktail dress. She looks wonderful. She smiles. She steps forward and takes his fa in her hands. She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Why are you all dressed up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him a glass of whiskey and closes his fingers around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL First of all, I missed you all day and I want to say I'm sorry. I'm sorry for the way I've been since that stupid play. I'm sorry for everything and... And I love you... Now wait here till I call you. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes, leaving Frank in stunned silence.    He takes a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From inside the house, the sound of the children's voices Whispering, giggling. Then April's voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL (O.S.) (CONT'D) Alright Frank! You can come in now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank enters the house.    Walks through the darkened liv room towards the light.    Enters the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is lit by the candles burning on a birthday cake

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNIFER, 7, MICHAEL, 5, and April sit around the table wearing paper birthday crowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sing Happy Birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank scrubs his skin, his scalp, his face: trying to was away Maureen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns off the water.   He stands there in the silence, regaining control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank steps out of the bathroom. April turns from the mir wearing the silk negligee and comes towards him with two glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Frank. I have had the most wonderful idea. I've been thinking about it all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK What's all this about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL You know how much money we have saved...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands Frank a glass of brandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough to live on for six months without you earning another dime. And with the money we could get from the house and the car, longer than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK What we get for the house...What are you talking about? Where are we going to live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL (CONT'D) You always said it was the only place you'd ever been that was worth living. So why don't we go there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK You're serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   What's stopping us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK What's stopping us? Well, I can think of a lot of things. For instance, what kind of a job could I possibly get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL You won't be getting any kind of job, because I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Don't laugh -- listen a minute! Have you any idea what they pay for secretarial positions in the government agencies in Europe? Embassies and those things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK No, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL I'm serious about this Frank. Do you think I'm kidding or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK No, I know, I know. I just have a couple of questions, is all. For one thing, do you mind telling me what exactly I'm supposed to be doing while you're out earning all this money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She draws back, shocked that he doesn't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Don't you see that's the whole idea? You'll be doing what you should've been allowed to do seven years ago. You'll have time, Frank. You'll have time to find out what it is that you actually want to do, and when you figure it out you'll have the time and the freedom to start doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Sweetheart, it's just not very realistic, is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Well, I happen to think this is unrealistic. I think it's unrealistic for a man with a fine mind to go on working like a dog year after year at a job he can't stand, coming home to a place he can't stand, to a wife who's equally unable to stand the same things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is silent.   How could anyone possibly argue with h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL (CONT'D) You want to know the worst part? Our whole existence here is based on this great premise that we're somehow very special and superior to the whole thing, and you know what I've realized...? We're not! We're just like everyone else. Look at us!   We've bought into the same ridiculous delusion. This idea that you have to resign from life and settle down the moment you have children. And we've been punishing each other for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Listen: we decided to move out here. No one ever forced me to take the job at Knox. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) I mean who ever said I was supposed to be a big deal, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL When I first met you, there was nothing in the world you couldn't do or be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I was a little wise guy with a big mouth, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL You were not! How can you even say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK ...All right... So, I'll have time. And God knows that's appealing. It's very appealing. And I mean, everything you say might make a certain amount of sense, if I had some definite talent maybe. If I were an artist or a writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL But Frank, listen to me: It's what you are that's being stifled here. It's what you are that's being denied and denied and denied in this kind of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK And what's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Don't you know...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her.   She gazes back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL (CONT'D) You're the most valuable and wonderful thing in the world... You're a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks at her. In that moment, he loves her more tha ever before. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL (CONT'D) This is our chance, Frank.   This is our one chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Why not...? Why the hell not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April throws her arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DING. The elevator doors slide open.   Frank steps onto t fifteenth floor, full of energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank arrives at his desk.   Casually tosses his briefcas down. Lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands nearby making idle chat with office co-worker ED SMALL, 36 and VINCE LATHROP, 33 - a pair of overgrown children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK Ah, Franklin. Good to see your shining face.  What's the news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I'm moving to Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.   And I'm moving to Tangiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank shrugs, smiles, picks up the Toledo file, scans it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches for his Dictaphone and clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK ...Intra-company letter to Toledo... Attention B.F. Chalmers, branch manager... With regard to recent and repeated correspondence, this is to advise that the matter has been... very satisfactorily taken in hand, period, paragraph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) We wholly agree that the existing brochure is unsuitable. To this end we have developed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lights the cigarette with a SNAP of his Zippo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) "Speaking of Production Control..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiles. He's making it up as he goes, and enjoying it. all meaningless now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April sits in the American Express office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLERK (O.S.) Here you are Mrs. Wheeler:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handsome CLERK smilingly hands her a stack of documents

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLERK (CONT'D) Here's the travellers checks you asked for... and your steamer reservations... and these I'll pass on to the embassy for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at them in her hands: it's real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, Frank, Ed and Vince sit crammed in a booth in a tin crowded Midtown Luncheonette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks pleased with himself.    The rest sit in stun silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK And when does this noble experiment commence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: September.     October at the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Vince exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's enjoying the effect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) I just happen to think people are better off doing some kind of work they actually like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ED (vague) Right, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VINCE (mumbled) Absolutely, absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK But... I mean, assuming there is a true vocation waiting for you. Wouldn't you be just as likely to discover it here as there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waitress puts the check on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK No... I don't think it's possible to discover anything on the fifteenth floor of the Knox building, and I don't think any of you do either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are silent.   Frank picks up the check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) This one's on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is standing leaning against a coffee bar in Grand Central Station. He is finishing a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is rush hour, and amidst the sea of people, he is the one not moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is watching all the people walking by with an air of detached amusement. As if he were now above them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank rides between train cars. The wind whips his hair. takes a deep pull from a pinched cigarette - then flicks straight as a bullet into the passing countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feels alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The commuter train slows into the station. A door swings open. And Frank leaps from the still moving train onto th platform. He slows to a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids dance back and forth through the sprinkler, shrieking with pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April sits on the steps in front of the house reading som material from the American Express office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up as Frank's car pulls into the drive. He step out of the car and comes towards her. She looks up and smiles. He drops his brief case on the ground and walks towards her. She meets him in the middle of the lawn, and they embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP - two fingers walk the journey from New York to Paris across the page of an atlas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Jennifer, dressed for bed, sit sandwiched bet April and Frank under the bedclothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL ...All the way to... here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause as the two kids stare at the Atlas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Well, sweetheart. It's a big world out there and we thought maybe we should go see a little bit of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL How far is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL A long way. We have to take a boat ride over the sea to get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNIFER I won't know anyone there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL I know. And neither will I. But remember when you started school? And now look how many friends you have...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank senses that they are a little concerned.   April an Frank look to one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK You'll never guess what they eat in Paris. You'll never guess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snails?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL And frog's legs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children dissolve into disgusted laughter.    April a Frank laugh with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bottom of the stairs, Shep hums a big band number he vigorously shines his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEP Buddappa banh!     Banh!   Banh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a swig of beer and lets out a satisfied belch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milly sits at a vanity table doing her face. She wears a floral dress and her hair's been done. She looks at Shep the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better get changed, they'll be here soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEP That what you're wearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILLY (panic) Don't you like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEP ...No... No. You look great, doll. Guess I better haul ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks into the bathroom.    Milly looks back at her reflection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small explosion of a beer can opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shep watches the golden liquid fill his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shep walks through the living room with his glass of beer He's halfway across the room, before he notices -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His four SONS dressed in matching pajamas, propped up on their elbows chewing gum at the television screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya gang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't even look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shep walks across the grass to the edge of his property. drinks and looks down over Revolutionary Road. He can see the Wheeler house. He takes a drink of beer, his eyes focused on the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shep wheels around. April and Frank are standing there wi Milly. April wears a new indigo silk dress. Her hair move in the warm breeze. She's never looked better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shep mixes drinks with his back to the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milly walks in and places two heaping trays of hors d'ouv on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Oh those look great.    I'm starving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April helps herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILLY April, I can't get over it - you look like the cat who ate the canary! Do you have something to tell us? A little bit of news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEP (disapproving) Not to pry or anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILLY (suddenly unsure) I'm not prying. Am I prying?    I didn't mean to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Actually, we have got some pretty important news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shep and Milly look up expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles conspiratorially at April.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) You want to tell `em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April smiles back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL We're going to Europe.    To Paris... To live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milly's face drops.    Shep is frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overlapping:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: September.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for? Because we've always wanted to. Because the kids are still young. Because it's beautiful. Shep, you tell her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's a great city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milly glances nervously at Shep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you make this decision?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... about a week ago... its hard to remember. We just suddenly decided to go, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a week ago, and you tell us now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had to get used to the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shep forces himself across the room and hands the Wheeler their drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what's the deal, Frank? You get a job over there, or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (smiles) No. Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEP What do you mean, `not exactly?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Frank won't be doing any kind of a job, because I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEP (to Frank) And what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I'm going to study... and I'm going to read and... I suppose I'm going to finally figure out what I want to do with my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEP ...While she supports you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Yes. While she supports me...   At least in the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL You wouldn't believe what they pay for secretarial work in government agencies over there. NATO and E.C.A. and those places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK The cost of living is dirt cheap compared to here, so we should be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL The truth is we just need something different. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not getting any younger and we don't want life to just pass us by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, it sounds wonderful, kids. I mean it; it really sounds wonderful. We'll certainly miss you, though - won't we, sweetie? Golly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris.   Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A   silence.   Shep's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milly sits on the edge of the bed in her night gown.   Sh brushing her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shep stands in the open doorway to the bathroom, doing up pyjamas. After a beat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milly looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this whole plan sounds a little immature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milly's face brightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, I'm so relieved. Me too... I was thinking that the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of man is going to sit around in his bathrobe picking his nose while his wife works all day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILLY I don't know, Shep.   I just don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milly is crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEP What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.   I'm just so relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down beside her.   She falls into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEP Come on. Don't cry. Please. It's all right. It's going to be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kid's shout from somewhere in the house.     Milly sits

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and April burst into the kitchen, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, their faces! You'd think we'd told them that we were swimming up the Yangtzee river or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughing, April hands Frank a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) You know what this is like, April? Talking like this? The whole idea of taking off to Europe this way? It's like the way I felt going up to the line the first time, in the war. I was probably just as scared as everyone else, but inside I never felt better. I felt alive. I felt full of blood. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) And everything looked more real. The guys in their uniforms. The snow on the fields, the trees. And all of us just... walking. I mean I was scared of course. But I kept thinking: this is it. This is the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL I felt that way once too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her.   And there's something in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL The first time you made love to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks over to her and kisses her passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they make love that way, face to face, with the light on, looking into each other's eyes, fully clothed, until comes inside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he comes, she makes a sound, almost inaudible, but it sounds like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds her, breathing heavily.    She strokes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank walks across the 15th floor, the atmosphere unusual abuzz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He arrives in his cubicle. Jack, Ed and Vance are talking hushed tones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ED Bart Pollock is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VINCE He's in Bandy's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (unimpressed) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small signal light illuminates on Frank's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ED Looks like he wants to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks around. They're all looking at him.     He lo over in the direction of Bandy's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.   Keep my name out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandy looks up from his desk.   An uncharacteristic smile

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warm) Frank. How are you? You know Bart Pollock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Well, we've never met, but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A massive MAN in tan gaberdine rises up from a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK Glad to know you Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds a file in his enormous hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK (CONT'D) Speaking of production control?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks away, ready for a dressing down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK (CONT'D) Frank... This is a crackerjack. They're just tickled to death in Toledo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps the file on the desk.    Frank can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close of a book: "Brighter French."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits on the couch, flipping absently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK You wouldn't have believed this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April enters carrying a plate of sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) He's perfect Presidential material in the worst sense. A million dollar smile and about three pounds of muscle between his ears. (mimicking Pollock's booming voice) "Frank, this is a crackerjack."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April looks around to be sure everything's in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL Wish I saw his face when you told him you were leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK ...Horse's ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOOT of a car horn.   April goes to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL I think this is them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the picture window, we see the Givings' car is pa in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Givings gets out of the car holding a tinfoil covere baking pan. Mr. Givings opens the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out steps JOHN, 30's, an institutional haircut and ill- fitting suit. He looks around the sunny neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen is suddenly crowded with the Givings, Frank a April.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overlapping:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Sorry to be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL You're not late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS The traffic was terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. GIVINGS Good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Wasn't it terrible, Howard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Route 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands are shook, the baking dish exchanged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL You didn't have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK The time they finish that stretch of road, they'll have to start all over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John stands by himself closest to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL And you must be John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence settles over the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Say hello, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN Nice to meetcha.   Heard a lot aboutcha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John smiles, exposing a mouthful of deeply-stained yellow teeth and high, eroded gums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Givings leads the group into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Where are your darling children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL They're at a birthday party.     Sorry they couldn't be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John walks around the room, stiff-legged, examining the b shelves, the paintings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN Don't worry. If I had a certified lunatic coming around the house, I'd probably get the kids out of the way too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April and Frank exchange a quick glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Oh, look at all this food! You didn't have to go to any trouble for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL It's just some sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April lifts the plate and offers it to John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL (CONT'D) John, would you like a sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He avoids her look, but he takes four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN Helen's been talking it up about you people for months. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN (CONT'D) The nice young Wheelers on Revolutionary Road, the nice young Revolutionaries on Wheeler road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polite laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Who'd like some sherry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Please, don't bother Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN I'd like some sherry. And I'll drink Helen's if she doesn't beat me to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April can't suppress a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly serious) But, hey... Listen, though. You got a high-ball glass...? Put a couple-three ice cubes in it, pour it up to the brim. That's the way I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I think I can do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Givings eats his sandwich, watching his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Oh, this is the most wonderful egg salad, April. You must tell me how you fix it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank hands John his high-ball glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN You a lawyer Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK No, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN I could use a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. GIVINGS John, let's not get started again about the lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN Pop, couldn't you just sit there and eat your wonderful egg salad, and quit horning in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Givings gives his son a level, warning look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN (CONT'D) See, I've got a good many questions to ask and I'm willing to pay for the answers... Now, I don't need to be told that a man who goes after his mother with a coffee table is putting himself in a weak position legally; that's obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and April exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS John, come and have a look out this fabulous picture window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Givings gets up and goes to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN If he hits her with it and kills her, that's a criminal case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Oh, look, the sun's coming out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN If all he does is break the coffee table and give her a certain amount of aggravation and she decides to go to court over it, that's a civil case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Maybe we'll see a rainbow!   John, come have a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN Ma, how about doing everybody a favor? How about shutting up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April's face.   She's not smiling now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. GIVINGS Steady down, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With her back to the room, Mrs. Givings closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I can look into it.   Maybe recommend someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John stares at Frank for any sign of condescension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN So, what do you do, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I work for Knox Business Machines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN You design the machines?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN Make `em, sell `em, repair `em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS All these questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I sort of help sell them, I guess. I work in the office. Actually, it's sort of a stupid job. I mean there's nothing В­ you know, interesting about it or anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS Oh, Frank...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN Whaddya do it for then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. GIVINGS Maybe Frank doesn't want to be questioned like this, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN Okay, okay, okay В­ I know it's none of my business. And besides, I know the answer. You want to play house, you got to have a job. You want to play very nice house, very sweet house, then you got to have a job you don't like. Anyone comes along and asks "Whaddya do it for?' he's probably on a four-hour pass from the State funny farm. All agreed...? Ma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John smiles his yellow grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. GIVINGS Sorry, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Don't be. I agree with everything you said, John. We both do. That's why I'm quitting the job in the fall and we're taking off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL We're moving to Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John looks over at his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN Did you know about this, Ma...? Wow. How do you feel about that, Ma? The nice young Wheelers are taking off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John bursts into a painful braying laugh.   It goes on an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Givings brings a hand to her brow - she's on the ver of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS ...John, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. GIVINGS Steady down, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April looks at Frank - the whole thing is in danger of go off the rails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK How about some fresh air, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John stops laughing abruptly.    He looks to his parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) If that's all right with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. GIVINGS I don't know if it's a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. GIVINGS ...If John wants to, I don't see the harm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, April and John walk through the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ground is freshly rained on and damp.    The sun is b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John buttons up his top button and pulls his sleeves down over his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL I hear you're a mathematician.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN You hear wrong.     It's all gone now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN You know what electrical shock treatments are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   Yes I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN I've had thirty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes his hat back and turns his head at April.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are scars on his forehead.       April can see them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN (CONT'D) Supposed to jolt out the `Emotional Problems.' Just jolted out the mathematics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN (mimicking) `How awful...' Why, because mathematics is so `interesting?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL No. Because the shocks must be awful and... well, because it's awful not to be able to do what it is you want to do. I think mathematics are dull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John stares at April.    He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN I like your girl, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN So, what do a couple of people like you have to run away from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK We're not running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John comes to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN And what's in Paris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL A different way of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK So maybe we are running... We're running from the hopeless emptiness of the whole life here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN The hopeless emptiness? Now, you've said it. Plenty of people are on to the emptiness, but it takes real guts to see the hopelessness... Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John continues walking.   Frank and April watch him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and April at the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL You know, he's the first person who seemed to know what we were talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK That's true. Maybe we are just as crazy as he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If being crazy means living life as if it matters then I don't care if we are completely insane. (beat) Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL I love you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small, attractive house bathed in sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank follows Bart Pollock as he cuts a swathe through an impressive midtown eatery. A small MAITRE D' scuttles in front of them. Bart nods, points at well-wishers, and mak a politician's show of knowing the staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK Tell you something, Frank. I'm a little sore at Bandy for the way he's kept you under a bushel all these years. This place okay, for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank smirks at the performance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK This is just fine, sir.   Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bart Pollock sits across an expanse of white tablecloth gripping a martini glass in one of his enormous paws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK One thing interests me, Frank, and one thing only: selling the electronic computer to the American businessman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK (CONT'D) That's why I'm assembling a team. Men like you, not your average salesmen... It'll mean more money, and I got to be honest, maybe more of a time commitment. But you'll be part of something exciting, Wheeler... Computers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Well, sir, it sounds exciting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks down at his plate.   He can't help himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) Do you happen to remember an Earl Wheeler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bart looks at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (CONT'D) Out of Yonkers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK Can't say that I do. Relation of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK My father. He worked at Knox almost twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK (thinking) Earl Wheeler... Earl Wheeler...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK No reason you would have heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK Well, I'm sure he was a good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank smiles.   Looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK There's something I should have mentioned earlier... I'm leaving the firm. In the fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK Another outfit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK No, it's not another outfit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bart holds up his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK Now look, Frank. Is it a question of money? Because if it is, there's no reason we can't get together on a satisfactory В­

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I appreciate that, but it's not money. It's more of a personal thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK A personal thing? I see. (looks down, clearly disapproving) Frank... Let me tell you something my father told me... A man only gets a couple chances in life. If he doesn't grab `em by the balls, it won't be long before he finds himself sitting around wondering how he got to be second rate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bart lets it hang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK So, do me a favor... Sleep on it. Discuss it with your wife. Because let's face it: where the hell would any of us be without our wives, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Frank's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK (CONT'D) And Frank, in all sincerity, if you do decide to join us, I believe it'll be a thing you'll never regret. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART POLLOCK (CONT'D) And I believe something else, too. I believe it'd be a fine memorial to your Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank finds himself surprised by his welling up of emotio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late. Frank is sitting in his cubicle over his Dictaphone. Jack is long gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK Knowing what you've got, comma, knowing what you need, comma, Knowing what you can do without, dash. That's inventory control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stubs out a cigarette in an overflowing ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen stops by Frank's cubicle.   She pretends to be surprised to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN Oh, hi Frank. Working late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK I got to dig myself out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN I heard you were getting promoted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank shrugs, no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN (CONT'D) Big shot. I guess your Dad would have been real proud, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (surprised she remembered) Huh. Yeah, I guess so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN (smiles sweetly) So... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: maybe I should buy you a drink or something? You know...? Celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's face.   We don't know which way he'll go.   He sm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.   She can't quite believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN I'll just get my coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits there a moment longer, thinking.    Then he fo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a television. Elmer Fudd points a gun at Bugs Bunny, a pulls the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank frowns into his French phrase book.   Mike is watch the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April works a sewing machine with a cigarette burning bes her. Jennifer stands beside her holding a stuffed Giraffe and a list, which she reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNIFER I'm going to take my doll carriage and my bear and my three Easter rabbits and my giraffe and all my dolls and my doll house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL I thought maybe we'd give the doll house to Madeline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNIFER No! I don't want to give it to Madeline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April has to stop to re-thread and she's losing patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL I already explained to you, the big things are going to be hard to pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank lowers the book.   He recognizes her tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNIFER But Madeline can have my bear and my Easter rabbits -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APRIL No! Just the big things. Look. Wouldn't you rather go outside and play with Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
